verses.verse: And He said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree of which I commanded you that you should not eat?”
Then the man said, ((Prov. 28:13)) “The woman whom You gave to be with me, she gave me of the tree, and I ate.”
And the LORD God said to the woman, “What is this you have done?” The woman said, (Gen. 3:4; 2 Cor. 11:3; 1 Tim. 2:14) “The serpent deceived me, and I ate.”

So the LORD God said to the serpent: “Because you have done this, You are cursed more than all cattle, And more than every beast of the field; On your belly you shall go, And (Deut. 28:15-20; Is. 65:25; Mic. 7:17) you shall eat dust All the days of your life.

And I will put enmity Between you and the woman, And between (John 8:44; Acts 13:10; 1 John 3:8) your seed and (Is. 7:14; Luke 1:31, 34, 35; Gal. 4:4) her Seed; (Rom. 16:20; (Rev. 12:7, 17)) He shall bruise your head, And you shall bruise His heel.”

To the woman He said: “I will greatly multiply your sorrow and your conception; (Is. 13:8; John 16:21) In pain you shall bring forth children; (Gen. 4:7) Your desire shall be for your husband, And he shall (1 Cor. 11:3; Eph. 5:22; 1 Tim. 2:12, 15) rule over you.”

Then to Adam He said, (1 Sam. 15:23) “Because you have heeded the voice of your wife, and have eaten from the tree (Gen. 2:17) of which I commanded you, saying, ‘You shall not eat of it’: (Gen. 5:29; Rom. 8:20-22; Heb. 6:8) “Cursed is the ground for your sake; (Job 5:7; 14:1; Eccl. 2:23) In toil you shall eat of it All the days of your life.
Both thorns and thistles it shall bring forth for you, And (Ps. 104:14) you shall eat the herb of the field.

(2 Thess. 3:10) In the sweat of your face you shall eat bread Till you return to the ground, For out of it you were taken; (Gen. 2:7; 5:5) For dust you are, And (Job 21:26; Eccl. 3:20) to dust you shall return.”
And Adam called his wife’s name (2 Cor. 11:3; 1 Tim. 2:13) Eve, because she was the mother of all living.
Also for Adam and his wife the LORD God made tunics of skin, and clothed them.
Then the LORD God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of Us, to know good and evil. And now, lest he put out his hand and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever”—
therefore the LORD God sent him out of the garden of Eden (Gen. 4:2; 9:20) to till the ground from which he was taken.

So (Ezek. 31:3, 11) He drove out the man; and He placed (Ex. 25:18-22; Ps. 104:4; Ezek. 10:1-20; Heb. 1:7) cherubim (Gen. 2:8) at the east of the garden of Eden, and a flaming sword which turned every way, to guard the way to the tree of (Gen. 2:9; (Rev. 22:2)) life.
(Cain Murders Abel) Now Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bore Cain, and said, “I have acquired a man from the LORD.”
Then she bore again, this time his brother Abel. Now (Luke 11:50, 51) Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.
And in the process of time it came to pass that Cain brought an offering of the fruit (Num. 18:12) of the ground to the LORD.
Abel also brought of (Num. 18:17) the firstborn of his flock and of (Lev. 3:16) their fat. And the LORD respected (Heb. 11:4) Abel and his offering,
but He did not respect Cain and his offering. And Cain was very angry, and his countenance fell.
So the LORD said to Cain, “Why are you angry? And why has your countenance fallen?
If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin lies at the door. And its desire is for you, but you should rule over it.”

Now Cain talked with Abel his brother; and it came to pass, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother and (Matt. 23:35; Luke 11:51; (1 John 3:12-15); Jude 11) killed him.
Then the LORD said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?” He said, (John 8:44) “I do not know. Am I (1 Cor. 8:11-13) my brother’s keeper?”
And He said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood (Num. 35:33; Deut. 21:1-9; Heb. 12:24; Rev. 6:9, 10) cries out to Me from the ground.
So now (Gen. 3:14; Deut. 11:28; 28:15-20; Gal. 3:10) you are cursed from the earth, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
When you till the ground, it shall no longer yield its strength to you. A fugitive and a vagabond you shall be on the earth.”
